Award.AwardTitle: Student Support for the 15th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for the 2016 Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS). WEIS fosters cross-disciplinary, cross-sector (i.e., academia, industry, nonprofit, and government), and cross-national discussion on information security. The focus on the economics of information security was chosen not only because of its intrinsic importance, but also because of its basis for bringing together social, computer, and information scientists and engineers to share knowledge, information and methods from their respective domains. WEIS covers issues that are core to the NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, and spans both the Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Directorates within the Foundation.

The WEIS conference draws a 50/50 split between US and European participants, with a small number of participants from Asia. The venue rotates between US and European locations, with two years in the US for every year in Europe.

All funds from this grant will go towards supporting US undergraduate and graduate student attendance at the WEIS conference, to be held in June 2016 at the University of California, Berkeley. This project will thus provide US students with valuable opportunities for students to meet and interact with notable researchers, thereby furthering their own research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of the economics of privacy and security has grown substantially since the first instance of the Workshop on the Economics of Information Security (WEIS). However, the workshop has remained the leading forum for interdisciplinary scholarship on information security, combining expertise from the fields of computer science and electrical engineering, economics, social science, business, law, and policy. This grant supported the 15th Workshop on the Economics of Information Security, which was held in June 2016 in Berkeley, California, hosted by the International Computer Science Institute (ICSI) and the University of California, Berkeley.

This year, WEIS received a record of 73 submissions, of which 21 were accepted. Paper sessions featured topics relating to security investment, online payments, user attitudes and perceptions, online privacy, malware and online crime, and incentives. This NSF support was used exclusively for 18 students to attend who otherwise could not, including three paper authors. These students came from universities spread across the country. Their attendance furthered their education by exposing them to cutting edge interdisciplinary research surrounding information security, allowed them to meet and interact with senior researchers in the field, gather ideas for potential new research directions and thesis topics, as well as disseminate their own research.
